text: hi all! *wrt content pruning*: would deindeixing pages from Google achieve the same result? or should we strictly prune them from our website? appreciate the help :wink:

elements.text: : would deindeixing pages from Google achieve the same result? or should we strictly prune them from our website? appreciate the help

text: I’m not sure what you want to achieve, are you speaking about pages you no longer want on your website?

elements.text: I’m not sure what you want to achieve, are you speaking about pages you no longer want on your website?

text: If you do remove them from your website, google will also soon deindex them (you can try speeding it up with the request deindexing tool in the search console)

elements.text: If you do remove them from your website, google will also soon deindex them (you can try speeding it up with the request deindexing tool in the search console)

text: just always be wary not to remove pages that have backlinks pointing to them, even though they are not ranking - it’s not the end of the world if you have a page that’s not ranking, but if it brought you good backlinks and you removed it, then it very well could be

elements.text: just always be wary not to remove pages that have backlinks pointing to them, even though they are not ranking - it’s not the end of the world if you have a page that’s not ranking, but if it brought you good backlinks and you removed it, then it very well could be

text: thanks <@UUKNSAKUH>! basically we have 100s of pages that drive 0 traffic (+ no backlinks). from what i know, removing them boosts traffic (since crawl budget goes to high traffic pages).

elements.text: ! basically we have 100s of pages that drive 0 traffic (+ no backlinks). from what i know, removing them boosts traffic (since crawl budget goes to high traffic pages).

text:
Setting a page to noindex prevents/removes it from Google’s index (assuming it can be crawled). But that’s it. It can still accumulate and pass PageRank, so I assume it can still influence other determinations made by Google’s systems.

Crawl budget isn’t an issue until you get into the millions of pages (if they update moderately - like once a week) or tens of thousands (if they update frequently - like daily).

Also, the assertion that removing pages boosts traffic since crawl budget goes to high traffic pages is incorrect. Crawl budget doesn’t influence traffic.

Lastly, traffic/backlinks shouldn’t be the basis for pruning content. The main issue revolves around quality of content. Don’t be the one that uses a butcher’s blade when a scalpel is what’s required.

Look to improve the content as opposed to giving it the axe.

elements.text:
Setting a page to noindex prevents/removes it from Google’s index (assuming it can be crawled). But that’s it. It can still accumulate and pass PageRank, so I assume it can still influence other determinations made by Google’s systems.

Crawl budget isn’t an issue until you get into the millions of pages (if they update moderately - like once a week) or tens of thousands (if they update frequently - like daily).

Also, the assertion that removing pages boosts traffic since crawl budget goes to high traffic pages is incorrect. Crawl budget doesn’t influence traffic.

Lastly, traffic/backlinks shouldn’t be the basis for pruning content. The main issue revolves around quality of content. Don’t be the one that uses a butcher’s blade when a scalpel is what’s required.

Look to improve the content as opposed to giving it the axe.

text: Deindexing will help with crawl budget, but if the content is bad enough that you want to prune it anyway, why not just delete it? Similarly to the point above, I think it would make the most sense to review it for quality in addition to the backlinks and then get rid of whatever content is no longer worth updating rather than leaving it on your site. The only reason I can see to deindex it is if you're planning on updating it anyway... and even then I wouldn't go to the effort of deindexing it in the meantime

text:
Hey Superpeeps, has anyone had their Linkedin account suspended and been able to have it reinstated?

This happened to me 2 months ago (unfairly I believe - here's <https://scm.ck.page/posts/it-s-been-a-frustrating-week|more info on what happened>), and after several attempts and back and forth emails with the LI team I got nowhere. I basically put it in the "too hard & frustrating basket" and left it alone for my own sanity.

I'm feeling now that I'm missing opportunities by not having a presence on LI, so I'd like to try again to get it reinstated.

Does anyone have any tips, guidance, or a contact that works at LI (who will actually listen and not throw terms and conditions in my face) that might be able to help?

attachments.title: It's been a frustrating week!
